instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.BKL_PWM: What is BKL_PWM? BKL_PWM sets the brightness of the screen. The system will send a PWM signal to BKL_PWM pin to set brightness. If this is low, backlight voltage will boost higher than PPBUS_G3H input, but not enough to make the screen light properly..
definitions.BKLT_EN: What is BKLT_EN? This signal enables backlight. Anytime you see a signal ending with “_EN” , that means this signal being present/high enables what it is referring to. This signal says “BKLT” before “_EN”. “BKLT” sounds short for “BACKLIGHT”, so it is safe to assume this signal enables backlight when present. .
definitions.PPHV_S0SW_LCDBKLT: What is PPHV_S0SW_LCDBKLT? PPHV_S0SW_LCDBKLT is a power rail that powers the backlight on the LCD screen, this is necessary to get the screen to light up..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight
threads.message:
Working on a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with no backlight

Have video but backlight missing

<SIGNAL>PPHV_S0SW_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL>  24 v

<SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL> 0.44v
<SIGNAL>BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> 2.88v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL> 0.44v"
Too low.
There is PWM signal, but DC value on a DMM should be higher however.

Do few PRAM reset first.
If no result, remove <RESISTOR>R7704</RESISTOR> and run a wire from <RESISTOR>R7715</RESISTOR> to <CAPACITOR>C7704</CAPACITOR>.
Confirm maxim backlight in this case (I hope).
Do again PRAM reset and finally resolder board in original state.
Let us know if then works.

BTW, backlight circuit of 00165 has lot of threads on the forum; just use the search function...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight
threads.message: 24 volts should be working....do a PRAM reset
